newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian folklore writer Amos Tutuola dies at 77.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian folklore writer Amos Tutuola dies at 77.

text.p: Nigerian folklore writer Amos Tutuola, who wrote several novels in his own peculiar English language, has died at the age of 77, newspapers said on Friday.
The independent Guardian said Tutuola died last Sunday in the southwestern Nigerian city of Ibadan. He had suffered for a long time from hypertension and diabetes.
Nigerian playwright Femi Osofisan of the University of Ibadan said Tutuola's death was a great loss to literature.
"I take it as another milestone in the passing away of that remarkable generation of extremely talented and profound individuals, which I refer to as the action group generation," he said.
Tutuola had only basic education but made a name in the literary world writing a series of novels in the 1950s and 60s published by Faber and Faber of London.
Among his most celebrated works were The Palmwine Drinkard and My Life in the Bush of Ghosts, which were also adapted into plays.
"He wrote English as best as he knows it and 'The Palmwine Drinkard' is a classic which told the story of village life in Nigeria poignantly," said Nigerian translator Buki Jukwey.
"He translated his native language Yoruba literally into English in his writings," she added.

Born in 1920 in Abeokuta, southwestern Nigeria, Tutuola attended the Salvation Army School in Lagos. Before coming to the limelight as a writer he was a trainee blacksmith and served in the Royal Air Force in Lagos during the second world war.
He worked variously as messenger in the Lagos labour office, storekeeper and later as a clerk in then Nigerian Broadcasting Corporation, now the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria.

"His works are African classics because they deal in folklores which are uniquely presented in refreshing idoms, imagery and similes that are truly African," said Remi Adedokun, a theatre arts lecturer at University of Ibadan.
